chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation
sanskrit:
सर्वगुह्यतमं भूयः शृणु मे परमं वचः।
इष्टोऽसि मे दृढमिति ततो वक्ष्यामि ते हितम्॥
transliteration:
sarva-guhyatamaṁ bhūyaḥ śṛṇu me paramaṁ vacaḥ |
iṣṭo'si me dṛḍham iti tato vakṣyāmi te hitam ||
translation: Hear again My supreme word, the most secret of all secrets. Because you are My beloved friend, I shall tell you what is for your benefit.
commentary:
This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita as Krishna prepares to reveal the ultimate teaching. By describing it as 'sarva-guhyatamam' (the most secret of all secrets), Krishna emphasizes that what follows is the essence and culmination of all previous teachings. This supreme instruction transcends even the profound knowledge already shared throughout the eighteen chapters.

Krishna's declaration that Arjuna is 'iṣṭa' (beloved) to Him establishes the foundation of divine grace. The teaching that follows is not merely philosophical instruction but a gift of love from the Supreme to His devotee. This personal relationship between the Divine and the devotee is crucial for receiving the highest wisdom. Krishna assures Arjuna that what He is about to reveal is for his ultimate welfare (hitam), indicating that the forthcoming verse will contain the most direct path to liberation and eternal happiness.

This verse serves as a prelude to verse 65, which contains the essence of bhakti yoga and surrender. By building anticipation and emphasizing both the secretive nature and the beneficial purpose of the teaching, Krishna ensures that Arjuna—and all readers of the Gita—approach the final instruction with the proper reverence and receptivity. The repetition of 'bhūyaḥ' (again) suggests that while this teaching may echo earlier themes, it represents their ultimate synthesis and most accessible application.
speaker: Krishna
